instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead after SSD swap
threads.message: So I did a dumb thing. A friend brought me his teen daughter's dead <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>...it was charging (made the tone when USB C charger connected) but no boot chime or video from internal or external displays. Rather than trying to repair it (I just moved offices and am still unpacking my bench, plus the broken machine is in nasty shape physically), I just offered to sell him a 1 year newer <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> unit I have and swap the SSDs. So I swapped her SSD into my known good machine, and ended up with a non-boot situation. USB C goes from 5v to 20v as expected, but 0.00A when battery is connected or disconnected. I went back to her dead machine and now have no charge tone there (with same voltage/current draw). I'm assuming I toasted something in each machine because I pulled the SSDs without disconnecting the batteries first? I checked to make sure I didn't knock anything off the boards during opening. Power rails on the newer machine seem ok, I haven't dug in much further because I'm still putting my bench back together. Just posting here to get confirmation that my idiot SSD yank move probably caused this...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead after SSD swap
threads.message: The new machine boots without SSD now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead after SSD swap
threads.message: Neither machine boots with OR without SSD. No sign of life aside from 20V at USB C meter and main rails OK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead after SSD swap
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is present at SSD connector; even with battery alone.
CPU can be damaged now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead after SSD swap
threads.message: So you're saying that if <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to another line in the SSD connector that goes to the CPU, the CPU is probably fried. Makes sense. Ok thank you!
